content: The "Community Savings and Investment Act of 2004" may be cited as the short title. It includes provisions for income tax on qualified community lenders. The "Community Savings and Investment Act of 2004" includes provisions for income tax on qualified community lenders, where the tax imposed for a taxable year is based on a percentage of taxable income exceeding certain thresholds. The term 'qualified community lender' refers to a bank that has a satisfactory record of meeting community credit needs, with local community loans comprising at least 60% of total outstanding loans, meeting ownership requirements, and having total assets not exceeding $1,000,000,000. Ownership requirements are met if the bank meets specified criteria. The paragraph discusses the criteria for a bank to be considered a qualified community lender, including ownership requirements based on the location of shareholders. The definition of a "bank" for the purpose of being a qualified community lender is based on the location of the main office or charter of the bank. Interests in the bank are owned by other qualified community lenders with the sole purpose of serving their banking needs. A local community loan is a loan originated by a bank to a resident of the community where the bank is chartered or operates an office accepting deposits. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a "related person" in relation to a bank, including affiliates, directors, officers, principal shareholders, and immediate family members. It also mentions the use of loan proceeds for trade or business purposes in a community. Qualified community lender income is taxed at different rates based on income levels: zero-rate for income up to $250,000 and 15 percent for income exceeding $250,000 but not exceeding $1,000,000. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003, with income determined under subchapter S. SEC. 3. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME TAXATION FOR INCOME DERIVED FROM BANKING SERVICES WITHIN DISTRESSED COMMUNITIES. This section amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for banking services in distressed communities. Gross income can exclude distressed community banking income if elected by the taxpayer. Distressed community banking income is the net income from a qualified depository institution conducting banking business in a distressed community. A qualified depository institution must be insured, located in a distressed community, and have at least 85% of its loans from within the community. The text discusses the requirements for a qualified depository institution to be considered a distressed community bank, including having at least 85% of its loans from within the community. The definition of a distressed community is also provided. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
